Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded community center, clutching my phone, my name badge, and my ballot. My sister’s trembling voice still echoed in my ears—she’d just called, sobbing, after getting terrible news from her doctor. I wanted nothing more than to step outside, call her back, and be the comforting presence she needed. But the election official’s voice cut through my thoughts: “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name was right in that range. The new line was longer, slower, and people grumbled as they shuffled over. I knew the rules: follow instructions, don’t cause trouble, respect the process. But my phone buzzed again in my pocket, and I imagined my sister alone, waiting for me to be there for her. I felt torn in two—my duty as a voter pulling me one way, my love as a sibling pulling me the other. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, caught between the demands of the moment and the needs of someone I loved.
